repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - National Water Rehabilitation,
            First Multi-State Water Supply, and Small Towns Water Supply
            and Sanitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The National Water Rehabilitation, the
            First Multi-State, and the Small Towns Water Supply projects
            were selected for this cluster assessment in order to
            evaluate the reasons for the failure of the Bank's
            assistance to the Nigerian water supply sector in the
            1979-2004 period.  These projects represent a clear
            evolution in the scope of World Bank lending: the first
            project was nationwide and concentrated on procurement and
            installation of equipment in selected water systems in each
            of the 36 Nigerian states and the National Federal
            Territory; the second project was restricted to two states
            (Kaduna and Katsina); and the third project directly
            assisted 16 small towns. This assessment rated the outcome
            of the National Water Rehabilitation Project as highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability highly unlikely, negligible
            institutional development Impact, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower.  For the First
            Multi-State Water Supply Project, the assessment concurred
            with the completion report, except that the PPAR rated the
            outcome as moderately satisfactory. The PPAR rated the
            outcome of the Small Towns Water Supply and Sanitation
            Project as satisfactory with likely sustainability,
            substantial institutional development impact and
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            There are three principal lessons: First, the targets under
            the MDGs for water supply and sanitation, focusing only on
            service coverage and access, need to be expanded to include
            the reliability and quality of water supplies.  Second,
            effective coordination between central, state and local
            governments requires demand-driven approaches where the
            consumers have the initiative. Third, maintenance merits
            priority over new works.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Small Towns Water Supply and
            Sanitation Program Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts; yet, the Bank performance
            is rated satisfactory, though the Borrower's was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons are drawn from the project,
            namely, that interventions should be geographically limited,
            i.e., location impacts supervision, and therefore
            implementation. The Bank needs to limit its interventions
            geographically so that adequate supervision (and adequate
            supervision funds) be physically possible, and a substantial
            impact made. Any intervention over a wide spatial
            distribution will challenge the quality of supervision, and
            dilute the impact. The states in the country, being
            responsible for water supply and sanitation (WSS) provision,
            should therefore be the implementing entities for water
            supply and sanitation projects. The federal
            government's role should be limited to monitoring and
            evaluation. In addition, given the local government's
            relationship with the communities, they should be involved
            in implementing community based projects, under the proviso
            of understanding and leveraging communities'
            capabilities. Although the project was not negatively
            impacted by a lack of donor coordination, it is evident that
            other donors are likely to repeat the experiences of this
            Bank funded project. Despite the Bank's efforts, other
            programs have thus far, not incorporated these lessons into
            ongoing activities. It does not help that the recipient
            federal ministries differ depending upon whether the support
            is a credit or a grant, the Federal Government and donors
            need to coordinate their activities so as to ensure more
            effective implementation. Furthermore, lessons also suggest
            encouraging 'self-supervision' by project
            executers, enhancing independent monitoring and evaluation
            capacity, and, focusing on sustainability - not asset
            building. It is recommended to scale-up the
            Government's Small Towns (STWSS) program, based on
            criteria where States are the implementers; geographic space
            is limited in accordance to project design and
            pre-determined capabilities; the Government's
            commitment to sustainable STWSS, is supported by the
            communities in their contribution to costs, not undermining
            through parallel schemes dispensing free WSS services. But
            most importantly, the Federal Government should establish a
            formal mechanism to coordinate the support it is receiving
            from donors in the water sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Nigeria - Small Towns Water Supply and
            Sanitation Program Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Small Towns Water Supply and
            Sanitation Program Pilot Project's objectives are to:
            a) assist efforts to facilitate access to safe water ad
            adequate sanitation by residents of small towns in Nigeria
            through the design and implementation of pilot water supply
            and sanitation facilities in selected small towns in project
            states; and b) determine the most efficient mechanism for
            delivery of sustainable schemes to be replicated later on
            throughout Nigeria. The project consists of three parts: 1)
            The first component is to promote ownership and community
            participation in the provision of water supply and
            sanitation facilities by carrying out extension activities
            aimed at sensitizing water users to foster the development
            of appropriate facilities. 2) The second component will
            finance the design and construction of pilot water supply
            and sanitation facilities. 3) The third component will
            support project management and project monitoring and evaluation.
